Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story: The morning sun filtered through the stained glass, painting the chapel in soft colors as the bell tolled for prayer. I stood in the hallway, habit pressed and rosary in hand, ready to join my sisters in the sacred silence of morning worship. Yet, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a rare intrusion. It was a message from my mother: “Don’t forget, today is the anniversary of Grandpa’s passing. We expect you to join the family ritual at home, just like every year.” My heart clenched. As a child, I was always the one to light the incense, to recite the prayers for our ancestors, to honor the traditions that bound us together. Now, as a nun, my life was shaped by a different rhythm, one that demanded my presence in the chapel at this very hour. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my family’s longing for continuity, my community’s call to devotion. I stood frozen, torn between the incense of my childhood and the incense of the altar, feeling the ache of being needed in two places at once.
